TopicTitle: Why did I lose Kerbals in a spashdown in this vehicle?

Articles.Content:
I finally rescued poor Jeb who was lost in a crazy oblong polar orbit (AP: 400,000km, Per:200km) stuck in just a spacesuit for like 20 days. I probably should have just launched with less Kerbals in the pod, but I elected to have a lander can attached. Looked like this for re-entry

Directly attached can with parachute on top.

landed in the ocean just fine about 8m/s. I was watching from the can, and saw the water splash against the view port, and everything looked fine. When I changed to external camera, however, Jeb was no longer listed as an occupant of my craft. When I went to the space facility to call for a recovery, it only listed just the pod (1 part). Why did I lose the can part? It didn't break apart on splash down, and I landed ass-first, not on the side. Did it go too 'deep' in the water, and was considered 'lost'?

Edited May 21, 2015 by SignalCorps
The crash tolerance for the Hitchhiker is only 6m/s. It popped right as you touched down and slowed the capsule enough to keep it from breaking.

Yeah, If you are in IVA of a part that is destroyed but is not the root, the IVA view stays until you switch away from it.

The hitchhiker cant take that splashdown.

A single Mk16-XL parachute is pretty much only suitable for the 2.5m pod on its own. If you have anything more than the pod to land, you'll need a number of radial parachutes and/or engine braking as well.

In terms of impact, 8m/s is fast. Ideally you should be aiming for 5m/s or less. Visualise a normal modern room, it is probably a little over 2m floor to ceiling. Now think of 4 times that height (8m). Now consider how long a second is. Put all that together, and you can hopefully see that it's a fast and violent impact.
You indeed were going too fast. If you can't visualise how fast 8ms actually is it accounts to 30kmh. And that storage container is a thin and lightweight compartment unlike the command module.
